questions.question: What is the vision for their vision for, I would say the future of computing?
So is this, is RISC-V in this whole process, is it potentially the future of all computing devices?
So do you think, do you agree with Dave Patterson and many folks that Moore's Law is dead?
And the year before you had a Pentium 33 and now it's twice as fast, right?
Can you summarize the key ideas of each of the five parts you've written about?
These things should be able to be in different processes on your machine and why just processes?
But maybe just to linger on it, like what does it take to run in your network fast?
Is it the compiler nerds working on that, or is it a whole new group of people?
Or can we run it on a, you know, with a RISC-V architecture, a bunch of CPUs?
I don't know that quantum computers are mature enough and accessible enough to be figured out yet, right?
I forgot to ask, what programming language do you think the simulation is written in?
Is this now time to go back to college and take a class and learn a new skill?
If you can afford to do that, is this time to like, literally move in with the parents, right?
And is there something that we can like, yeah, have you observed that in other places?
What happens when I make a classification that's wrong and now I hurt somebody, right?
So I have access to the GPT-3 API, would I be able to generate Swift code, for example?
How do I say I want a webpage that's got a shopping cart and this and that?
Are we just pattern matching based on what we have and then reverse justify it to ourselves?
How can I take what I'm good at and like bring it into the world?
And so we're doing our thing, we think we have purpose, but do we really?
